The current playoff status in the NHL is the Tampa Bay Lightning vs Montreal Canadiens in a best of 7 finals. The score is 3-0, favoring TPL, and there is approximately a 40% chance in the match-up, according to betting websites, that the Tampa Bay Lightning will lose in game 4. This means that, in the most basic assumption, that we can generalize this probability, we have that the Montreal Canadiens will win the Stanley Cup if they win the next 4 games straight which has a (.4)^4 chance of occurrring, or 2.56%.  There are other factors to consider here, i,e how home field advantage may play into the probabilities, or how momentum may affect player mindset. That being said, as a conservative estimate, we can give the TBL approximately a 96% chance of wining, with the other team (Canadiens) being given a slight cushioning at 4%.

Currently, the lightning is up 3-1 in the finals, needing only 1 more game to win. They won the first three games, dropping only the most recent one. This already implies 98% chance of them winning, assuming the odds of lightning winning any one game is 75%. In reality, this figure should be higher since it's only accounting for playoff games, where it's more likely for the weaker team to squeeze out a win from mistakes. Thus, I have the lightning winning at 98%, with the only chance of losing should a player be injured or other unexpected issues.

Down a little upon learning that the Canadiens have 12 times more Stanley Cup wins than the Lightning in the past century. However, it is relatively rare that a team down 3 losses makes a comeback to win the Stanley Cup.

At this point in time, the Tampa Bay Lightning are up 2-0 over the Montreal Canadiens. Using sports betting odds of (-1250 TB and +800 MTL), I've estimated that the TB Lightning have a 91% chance to win (averaging the odds). Additionally, hockey teams down 2-0 in a playoff series have only come back to win the series 12.7% of the time, giving a baseline of about 87%. Given that the Lightning won the first two games handily, by differentials of 4 and 2 goals, they would have odds better than 87% to win.

Obviously it's a little late to be making this estimate, but we are now down to the last two teams.  The lighting are already up 2-0, having won 5-1 and 3-1 in the first two games.  Historically, teams with a 2-0 lead in hockey are 293-48 (about 86%).  However, the lightning have won the first two games in convincing fashion, making a comeback seem even less likely.  However, I still give the Canadiens a 10% to come back because they are at home for the next two games, which historically makes them a slight favorite in each game.  After game 3, I will re-update my estimate based on final outcome and performance.
No idea who's playing the Canadians in the final, I never followed ice hockey and only found out about Montreal qualifying by coincidence. Money's on them.

This late into the competition, the finals will be between the Montreal Canadiens (another team) and the Tampa Bay Lightning. Trying to be as objective as possible (as a Maple Leafs fan), the Canadiens will be huge underdogs in the finals. Since the start of the 2000s decade of hockey, the Lightning have won 2 Stanley Cups (and are reigning champions), while the Canadiens haven't won since 1993. Out of the 52 games they've played since the start of the 2010/2011 season, Tampa Bay has won 29. If we condense that time frame to since the start of the 2014/2015 season, Tampa Bay has won 21/31. If we use 21/31 as the probability that Tampa Bay wins an independent game, there's about an 84.3% base probability that they take the whole thing. I think this base probability mostly encompasses the fact that Tampa Bay has the objectively stronger and deeper team. The way the Canadiens could win, however, is continuing to leverage their special teams, which have been especially lethal in the playoffs (27/30 penalty kill in the playoffs, 3 shorthanded goals scored, 6 powerplay goals scored). On the other hand, Tampa Bay has a strong powerplay and they went 8/20 in their first round matchup against the Panthers. It'll really be interesting to see how these two match up on special teams, and I think it'll be the main driver the Canadiens need to take this series.

Looked into this a little more since I'm just ripping off betting sites. Long story short, subtracting a set % from each implied probability is the way to go, don't normalize them. The way betting site odds are designed is that the implied probabilities of the odds are higher than the actual probabilities they estimate, with the markup over the actual probability called the vigorish or vig. That's why if you calculate the implied probability from the sportsbook averages they'll sum to more than 100%, in the case of the source I'm using 151% currently (https://www.sportsbettingdime.com/nhl/stanley-cup-odds/). For example if an actual probability is 25%, they set the odds at 30%, since 30% pays less than 25%, so its usually profitable to have probabilities sum to >100%. The way people here seem to be getting a ~40% chance for "another team or no team" seems to be based on normalizing the averages, or reducing them all by the same percentage (doing that to the aforementioned numbers gives 42% chance of other/none), but at least from what I've read that doesn't reflect how vig is actually determined. Normalization reduces all probabilities by the same proportion, but bookmakers will usually include a proportionally much higher vig on the smaller probabilities (i.e. saying a 1% chance is actually 2%, or a 100% markup), and a smaller one on the favorites (20% as maybe 22%, for a 10% markup). So normalizing incorrectly penalizes favorites and rewards underdogs relative to what the bookmakers actually do.  Saying there's a 40% chance of a team winning who isn't one of the top 5 favorites (out of only 16 teams) is a fairly spicy take, moreso than the normalized approach to sportsbook odds would imply. Looking at odds from before Round 1 for Stanley Cups since 1990, only 27% of eventual winners ranked below 5th, and 27% of winners had odds of >+1000. So normalization is at odds with accounts of how bookmakers operate, and to an extent at odds with the history of how those odds perform in practice.  The options for getting rid of vig are generally normalization (not optimal as explained), equal distribution which is where you subtract a set percentage from each probability, or a power based approach outlined here (https://www.researchgate.net/publication/305687456_ADJUSTING_TRUE_ODDS_TO_ALLOW_FOR_VIGORISH). The power approach doesn't adequately adjust the lower probabilities in my opinion, they still sum to 38%, my guess being because the vig is huge in this set of bets. 51% is a huuuuge margin (the power article mentions vig ranging from 2-20%) and that margin would be difficult to achieve using a single formula approach without making your bets on the favorites very distorted and clearly non-competitive with other sites, so the bets on underdogs are probably inflated beyond what a simple power formula would suggest. So I opt to use the equal distribution approach, and remove 3.2% from each implied probability. It's simple, but makes sense given how bookmakers operate, and gives an estimate for other/none (29%) that's consistent with how hockey odds have performed in the past.

Average of current sportsbook average odds fixed to sum to 100% (https://www.sportsbettingdime.com/nhl/stanley-cup-odds/) and moneypuck (http://moneypuck.com/predictions.htm) with double weight to sportsbooks, and with a 1.2x multiplier on the top 5 teams added afterward because I'm greedy and it'll definitely come back to bite me when the Bruins win.

Hockey is prone to fights and injuries

I agree with the betting odds approach of @Awisdomofwombats at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1264819. In addition, as my husband played hockey in college and one friend has coached high school hockey and another used to call hockey games (takes a special kind of brain -- he says it goes straight from the eyes to the mouth without conscious thinking) we qualify as hockey fans. And one thing I always have noticed, it is hard to predict! There is so much of an element of chance in each game. If hockey finals and semifinals were to be decided by seven games each, it would be far more predictable. However, hockey is like football in that players get badly bruised or even too injured to play. So series games won't happen and injuries or even just the erratic behavior of a sliding, flying disk make these hard ot predict.

All these teams will likely make the playoffs. Out of the West, I'd give the Avs about a 40% chance of emerging and Vegas about a 24% chance. I'd give Toronto a 40% chance of emerging from the North. With Tampa and Carolina each a 28% chance of advancing from the South. Once we are down to 4 teams, I'd give them all roughly equal chances, but with a slight advantage to those with the stronger records and stronger playoff goaltending (TBD later on). I'll revise these prior to the playoffs.
I generally don't find the top seed to be that predictive of who makes the finals so I gave each team fairly similar odds.

Carolina, Toronto, and Colorado are all playing well over the past 10 games so they have slightly better odds as it would seem they are playing well heading into the end of the season. With hockey though once the playoffs start the highest seeds and best teams aren't as likely to win as in other sports. You get a goalie that gets hot and they can win a series to knock a favorite out. With the standings being close its hard to pick any favorite.
